claim.statement_location: Main text Results section: "Social distancing measures decreased the mobility by an additional 23% (95%CI: 20%, 27%)."

data.source: Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) based on planned trips in the Citymapper app; implementation dates of governmental social distancing measures from official government and media websites.
data.wave_or_subset: 41 urban cities globally; daily data from March 2, 2020 to March 26, 2020.
data.sample_size: 1,025 observations across 41 cities (25 observations per city).
data.access_details: CMI referenced at https://citymapper.com/cmi. Government and media websites for policy dates.
data.notes: CMI reflects planned trips in the Citymapper app and does not include personal automobile navigation; may not generalize to populations not using public transport. Higher transmission risk in public transport noted by authors.

method.description: The authors downloaded Citymapper Mobility Index data for 41 cities from March 2–26, 2020, compiled dates when cities instituted social distancing measures (closing non-essential businesses, classified as moderate or intense), and estimated effects of time and these measures on mobility using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model.
steps: Download daily Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) data for 41 cities from March 2 to March 26, 2020.
Tabulate dates of governmental social distancing measures from official government and media websites.
Classify a city as having instituted social distancing if non-essential businesses were closed; further classify intensity as moderate or intense.
Construct a panel dataset with city-day observations.
Estimate the effect of time and social distancing measures on mobility using a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model.
method.outcome_variable: Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) expressed as percent of baseline.
method.independent_variables: Time (days from March 2 to March 26); indicator for social distancing measures (instituted vs not); classification of measure intensity (moderate vs intense).

results.summary: Median mobility decreased from 100% (IQR 94%, 107%) on March 2 to 10% (IQR 7%, 17%) on March 26. Mobility declined on average by 3.4% per day (95% CI: 3.3%, 3.6%). Instituting social distancing measures was associated with an additional 23% reduction in mobility (95% CI: 20%, 27%). No difference was observed between moderate and intense measures.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Daily change in mobility (per day from March 2 to March 26)
Additional change in mobility associated with social distancing measures

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19 related social distancing measures and reduction in city mobility
